We aim to guarantee differential privacy, which is a crypographically-motivated notion of privacy [50]. We define Î±â‰¥0ğ›¼0\alpha\geq 0 as privacy risk. Formally, we have:101010Note that (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta)-differential privacy is also known as (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, as in [8].

Definition 6 ((Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta)-differential privacy (DP)).

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be a positive real number and ğ’µğ’µ{\mathcal{Z}} be a randomized algorithm. The algorithm ğ’µğ’µ{\mathcal{Z}} is said to provide (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta)-DP if, for any two datasets ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1\mathcal{D}_{1} and ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2\mathcal{D}_{2} that differ on a single element, ğ’µğ’µ{\mathcal{Z}} satisfies

Prâ¡[ğ’µâ€‹(ğ’Ÿ1)=y]â‰¤expâ¡(Î±)â‹…Prâ¡[ğ’µâ€‹(ğ’Ÿ2)=y]+Î²,âˆ€y.Prğ’µsubscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ‘¦â‹…ğ›¼Prğ’µsubscriptğ’Ÿ2ğ‘¦ğ›½for-allğ‘¦\displaystyle\displaystyle\Pr[{\mathcal{Z}}(\mathcal{D}_{1})=y]\leq\exp\left(\alpha\right)\cdot\Pr[{\mathcal{Z}}(\mathcal{D}_{2})=y]+\beta,~{}\forall y. (51)

The above definition is reduced to the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-DP when Î²=0ğ›½0\beta=0, as in [51]. As we will show, one can achieve (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta)-DP by adding noise sampled from Gaussian distributions to gradients.

VI-B2 Secure Multi-Party Computation

For preserving the privacy of agentsâ€™ inputs without revealing them to others, the server aims to securely aggregate their gradients in each iteration.111111Note that MPC protocols are only able to protect the training data during the learning process, whereas the resulting model of a federated learning algorithm still relies on the differential privacy techniques (by adding noise in our proposed DP-FFL algorithm) against inferring private data of each agent. To this end, we consider secure multi-party computation (MPC) protocols that enable one to jointly aggregate their private inputs. Examples of these are protocols that employ cryptographic techniques (e.g., homomorphic encryption and secret sharing). In this work, we do not focus on improving or evaluating the MPC protocols, since the methods we propose can be implemented using standard MPC techniques.121212A concrete example of the standard MPC technique in federated learning frameworks can be found in [8, 9].

VI-B3 Algorithm and Mechanism Description

We are ready to introduce the Differentially Private Faithful Federated Learning (DP-FFL) algorithm in Algorithm 2, which also consists of two phases. Compared to the FFL algorithm in Algorithm 1, we add noise in lines 9, 24, and 28 based on

Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\sigma^{2} =16â€‹Lf2â€‹(T1+Kâ€‹T2)â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)K2â€‹n(1)2â€‹Î±2absent16superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“2subscriptğ‘‡1ğ¾subscriptğ‘‡21ğ›½superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle=\frac{16L_{f}^{2}(T_{1}+KT_{2})\log(1/\beta)}{K^{2}n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}} (52)
ÏƒP2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ƒ2\displaystyle\sigma_{P}^{2} =16â€‹Kâ€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)n(1)2â€‹Î±2,absent16ğ¾1ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle=\frac{16K\log(1/\beta)}{n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}, (53)

where n(1)subscriptğ‘›1n_{(1)} is the size of smallest local dataset among all agents ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K}. We also adopt the Scalable VCG payment from Definition 5 in the payment computation phase of Algorithm 2.

In the following, we introduce the DP-FFL mechanism associated to Algorithm 2:

Definition 7 (The DP-FFL Mechanism).

The DP-FFL mechanism â„³P=(ğ’œ,ğ’®m,ğ°âˆ—,ğ’«)superscriptâ„³Pğ’œsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘šsuperscriptğ°ğ’«\mathcal{M}^{\rm P}=(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{S}^{m},\boldsymbol{w}^{*},\mathcal{P}) satisfies, for all agents kâˆˆğ’¦,ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K},

skm={âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(ğ’˜â€‹[t])}tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ’kandAk={âˆ‡F~kâ€‹(ğ’˜â€‹[t])}tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ’k,formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ’˜delimited-[]ğ‘¡ğ‘¡subscriptğ’¯ğ‘˜andsubscriptğ´ğ‘˜subscriptâˆ‡subscript~ğ¹ğ‘˜ğ’˜delimited-[]ğ‘¡ğ‘¡subscriptğ’¯ğ‘˜\displaystyle s^{m}_{k}=\{\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}[t])\}_{t\in\mathcal{T}_{-k}}\quad{\rm and}\quad A_{k}=\{\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}[t])\}_{t\in\mathcal{T}_{-k}}, (54)

where ğ’¯âˆ’l=â‹ƒjâˆˆ{0}âˆªâ„’\{l}{1â‰¤tâ‰¤T2}subscriptğ’¯ğ‘™subscriptğ‘—0\â„’ğ‘™1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡2\mathcal{T}_{-l}=\bigcup_{j\in\{0\}\cup\mathcal{L}\backslash\{l\}}\{1\leq t\leq T_{2}\}. The output global model ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\boldsymbol{w}^{*} and each agent kğ‘˜kâ€™s payment ğ’«ksubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜\mathcal{P}_{k} are determined in (48) and (50), respectively.

We re-define the gradient bound specific for Algorithm 2 in the following:

Definition 8 (Gradient Bound).

The gradient bound Lfsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“L_{f} is defined as for each agent kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K},131313For readability, we are overloading the notation Lfsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“L_{f} to avoid introducing additional parameter names.

âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ’˜Fkâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ¥2â‰¤Lf,subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ’˜subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ’˜2subscriptğ¿ğ‘“\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla_{\boldsymbol{w}}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})\right\rVert_{2}\leq L_{f}, (55)

for all ğ°âˆˆ{ğ°â€‹[t]}tâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,T1}âˆª{ğ°lâ€‹[t]}lâˆˆâ„’,tâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,T2}âˆªğ’²âˆ—,ğ°subscriptğ°delimited-[]ğ‘¡ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘™delimited-[]ğ‘¡formulae-sequenceğ‘™â„’ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘‡2superscriptğ’²\boldsymbol{w}\in\{\boldsymbol{w}[t]\}_{t\in\{0,1,...,T_{1}\}}\cup\{\boldsymbol{w}_{l}[t]\}_{l\in\mathcal{L},t\in\{0,1,...,T_{2}\}}\cup\mathcal{W}^{*}, where {ğ°â€‹[t]}tâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,T1}âˆª{ğ°lâ€‹[t]}lâˆˆâ„’,tâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,T2}subscriptğ°delimited-[]ğ‘¡ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘™delimited-[]ğ‘¡formulae-sequenceğ‘™â„’ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘‡2\{\boldsymbol{w}[t]\}_{t\in\{0,1,...,T_{1}\}}\cup\{\boldsymbol{w}_{l}[t]\}_{l\in\mathcal{L},t\in\{0,1,...,T_{2}\}} are described in Algorithm 2 and ğ’²âˆ—superscriptğ’²\mathcal{W}^{*} is defined in (31).

We now show that DF-FFL achieves the following privacy property:

Proposition 9 (Proof in Appendix IX-L).

Algorithm 2 is (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta)-differentially private.

Proof of Proposition 9 is based on [8] and [53]. Similar to Proposition 4, we can also prove (E1) for the DF-FFL mechanism in the following:

Proposition 10 (Proof in Appendix IX-M).

In Algorithm 2, if we choose step sizes such that Î·1=Î·2â‰¤1/Lgsubscriptğœ‚1subscriptğœ‚21subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{1}=\eta_{2}\leq 1/L_{g} and numbers of iterations T1=ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(K2â€‹n(1)2â€‹Î±2dâ€‹Lf2â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)))subscriptğ‘‡1ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“21ğ›½T_{1}=\mathcal{O}\left(\log\left(\frac{K^{2}n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}{dL_{f}^{2}\log(1/\beta)}\right)\right) and T2=ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(K2â€‹n(1)2â€‹Î±2dâ€‹Lf2â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)))subscriptğ‘‡2ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“21ğ›½T_{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\log\left(\frac{K^{2}n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}{dL_{f}^{2}\log(1/\beta)}\right)\right),141414the big-ğ’ªğ’ª\mathcal{O} notation hides other log\log, Lgsubscriptğ¿ğ‘”L_{g}, and Î¼ğœ‡\mu terms. the following risk bound is true with a probability of 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta:

Eâ€‹(ğ’˜âˆ—)âˆ’minğ’˜â¡Eâ€‹(ğ’˜)â‰¤ğ¸superscriptğ’˜subscriptğ’˜ğ¸ğ’˜absent\displaystyle E(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})-\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}E(\boldsymbol{w})\leq C1â€‹Lf2â€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(Kâ€‹n(1))â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)Kâ€‹n(1)2â€‹Î±2subscriptğ¶1superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“2ğ‘‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘›11ğ›½ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle~{}C_{1}\frac{L_{f}^{2}d\log(Kn_{(1)})\log(1/\beta)}{Kn_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}
+âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦1nkâ€‹Lâ„“2â€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(2â€‹d/Î´)2â€‹Î¼â€‹K2,subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ¿â„“2ğ‘‘2ğ‘‘ğ›¿2ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2\displaystyle~{}+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{1}{n_{k}}\frac{L_{\ell}^{2}d\log(2d/\delta)}{2\mu K^{2}}, (56)

for some constants C1>0subscriptğ¶10C_{1}>0.

VI-C Three-Way Tradeoffs between Privacy, Accuracy, and the Iterations Needed

We will discuss three-way performance tradeoffs in the following:

Proposition 11 (Proof in Appendix IX-N).

If we choose constant step sizes Î·1â‰¤1/Lgsubscriptğœ‚11subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{1}\leq 1/L_{g}, Î·2â‰¤1(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Lgsubscriptğœ‚21ğ¾1subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{2}\leq\frac{1}{(K-1)L_{g}}, Lâ‰¥minâ¡{K,Lgâ€‹(Kâˆ’1)2â€‹Ïµâ€‹LfÎ¼}ğ¿ğ¾subscriptğ¿ğ‘”ğ¾12italic-Ïµsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğœ‡L\geq\min\left\{K,\sqrt{\frac{L_{g}(K-1)}{2\epsilon}}\frac{L_{f}}{\mu}\right\}, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, and the iterations as

T1=T2=âŒˆlogâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)logâ¡(Câˆ’1)âŒ‰,subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1\displaystyle T_{1}=T_{2}=\left\lceil\frac{\log\left(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A}\right)}{\log(C^{-1})}\right\rceil, (57)

then Algorithm 2 leads to a bounded expected payment accuracy loss:

|ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜absent\displaystyle\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right|\leq Aâ€‹(1+logâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)logâ¡(Câˆ’1))+Ïµ,ğ´1ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1italic-Ïµ\displaystyle~{}A\left(\frac{1+\log(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A})}{\log(C^{-1})}\right)+\epsilon, (58)

for all agents kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K}, where

Ağ´\displaystyle A =8â€‹Î·2â€‹dâ€‹Lf2â€‹(K+1)â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)Î¼â€‹K2â€‹(Kâˆ’1)â€‹n(1)2â€‹Î±2,absent8subscriptğœ‚2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“2ğ¾11ğ›½ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle=\frac{8\eta_{2}dL_{f}^{2}(K+1)\log(1/\beta)}{\mu K^{2}(K-1)n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}, (59a)
Bğµ\displaystyle B =(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Lf22â€‹Î¼,absentğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“22ğœ‡\displaystyle=\frac{(K-1)L_{f}^{2}}{2\mu}, (59b)
Cğ¶\displaystyle C =1âˆ’(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·2.absent1ğ¾1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚2\displaystyle=1-(K-1)\mu\eta_{2}. (59c)

Proposition 11 suggests a three-way tradeoff among privacy (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta), the iterations needed (T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1} and T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2}), and accuracy |ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right|. That is, by fixing Î²ğ›½\beta and properly selecting Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2}, one can improve two performance metrics by trading off the third. To see this, we consider the following three scenarios as guidelines to make such a three-way tradeoff:

  1. 1.

    To improve both privacy and iteration complexity by sacrificing accuracy, one can set Î±â†’0â†’ğ›¼0\alpha\rightarrow 0 to ensures privacy and set Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2} as a positive constant. In this case, we have that Aâ†’âˆâ†’ğ´A\rightarrow\infty, and hence T1=T2â†’0subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2â†’0T_{1}=T_{2}\rightarrow 0. However, the payment accuracy loss in (58) diverges to infinity, i.e., |ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|â†’âˆâ†’ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right|\rightarrow\infty.

  2. 2.

    To improve both accuracy and iteration complexity by sacrificing privacy, one can set Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2} in such a way that Î·2/Î±2subscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ›¼2\eta_{2}/\alpha^{2} is constant (and hence Ağ´A is also constant). Further, by increasing Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2} (and hence increasing Î±ğ›¼\alpha as well), we have that Cğ¶C decreases, and hence logâ¡(logâ¡(Câˆ’1))/logâ¡(Câˆ’1)superscriptğ¶1superscriptğ¶1\log(\log(C^{-1}))/\log(C^{-1}) decreases. Therefore, such a strategy decreases T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1}, T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2}, and |ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right| at the same time. However, Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2} is upper-bounded by the maximal step size 1(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Lg1ğ¾1subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\frac{1}{(K-1)L_{g}}.

  3. 3.

    To achieve perfect accuracy |ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|â†’0â†’ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜0\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right|\rightarrow 0, one needs to sacrifice both iteration complexity, privacy, and scalability. Specifically, by setting Î±â†’âˆâ†’ğ›¼\alpha\rightarrow\infty, it follows that Aâ†’0â†’ğ´0A\rightarrow 0 and hence T1=T2â†’âˆsubscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2â†’T_{1}=T_{2}\rightarrow\infty. Letting L=Kğ¿ğ¾L=K as well, we have |ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’«kâˆ—]âˆ’ğ’«kVCG|â†’0â†’ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’«VCGğ‘˜0\left|\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{P}_{k}^{*}]-\mathcal{P}^{\rm VCG}_{k}\right|\rightarrow 0.

We present a numerical example of Proposition 11 in Fig. 2, which compares the iterations needed and payment accuracy loss bounds at different Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2}. An interesting observation is that the payment accuracy loss bound hardly changes when Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2} decreases. This results from the fact that logâ¡((1âˆ’(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·2)âˆ’1)â‰ˆ(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·2superscript1ğ¾1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚21ğ¾1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚2\log((1-(K-1)\mu\eta_{2})^{-1})\approx(K-1)\mu\eta_{2}, which makes A/logâ¡(Câˆ’1)ğ´superscriptğ¶1A/\log(C^{-1}) almost constant if we only tune Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2}. On the other hand, fixing the step size Î·2subscriptğœ‚2\eta_{2}, T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1} and T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} decrease in Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the payment accuracy loss bound increases in Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

VI-D Properties

Collectively, in this subsection, we will show that the DP-FFL algorithm (and the DP-FFL mechanism) satisfies (E2) and (E3) approximately and (E4) exactly.

Corollary 2 (Faithful Implementation).

If we choose Î·1â‰¤1/Lgsubscriptğœ‚11subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{1}\leq{1}/{L_{g}}, Î·2â‰¤1(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Lgsubscriptğœ‚21ğ¾1subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{2}\leq\frac{1}{(K-1)L_{g}} T1=T2=âŒˆlogâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)/logâ¡(Câˆ’1)âŒ‰subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1T_{1}=T_{2}=\left\lceil\log\left(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A}\right)/\log(C^{-1})\right\rceil, and Lâ‰¥minâ¡{K,Lgâ€‹(Kâˆ’1)2â€‹Ïµâ€‹LfÎ¼}ğ¿ğ¾subscriptğ¿ğ‘”ğ¾12italic-Ïµsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğœ‡L\geq\min\left\{K,\sqrt{\frac{L_{g}(K-1)}{2\epsilon}}\frac{L_{f}}{\mu}\right\}, then the DP-FFL mechanism is (Ïµ~,Î´~)~italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿(\tilde{\epsilon},\tilde{\delta})-faithful, where

Ïµ~=~italic-Ïµabsent\displaystyle\tilde{\epsilon}= 2â€‹Ïµ+2â€‹Aâ€‹(1+logâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)logâ¡(Câˆ’1))+âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦1nkâ€‹Lâ„“2â€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(2â€‹d/Î´~)2â€‹Kâ€‹Î¼2italic-Ïµ2ğ´1ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ¿â„“2ğ‘‘2ğ‘‘~ğ›¿2ğ¾ğœ‡\displaystyle 2\epsilon+2A\left(\frac{1+\log(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A})}{\log(C^{-1})}\right)+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{1}{n_{k}}\frac{L_{\ell}^{2}d\log(2d/\tilde{\delta})}{2K\mu}
+Dâ€‹Lf2â€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(Kâ€‹n(1))â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)n(1)2â€‹Î±2,ğ·superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“2ğ‘‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘›11ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle+D\frac{L_{f}^{2}d\log(Kn_{(1)})\log(1/\beta)}{n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}, (60)

and A,B,ğ´ğµA,B, and Cğ¶C are defined in (59), and Dğ·D is some positive constant.

Corollary 2 is a direct application of Propositions 6 and 11 and Theorem 2; the three terms on the right-hand side of (60) come from Theorem 2, Proposition 11, and Proposition 6, respectively.

Corollary 3 (Risk-Bound-Based Voluntary Participation).

If we choose Î·1â‰¤1Lgsubscriptğœ‚11subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{1}\leq\frac{1}{L_{g}}, Î·2â‰¤1(Kâˆ’1)â€‹Lgsubscriptğœ‚21ğ¾1subscriptğ¿ğ‘”\eta_{2}\leq\frac{1}{(K-1)L_{g}} T1=T2=âŒˆlogâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)/logâ¡(Câˆ’1)âŒ‰subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1T_{1}=T_{2}=\left\lceil\log\left(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A}\right)/\log(C^{-1})\right\rceil, and Lâ‰¥minâ¡{K,Lgâ€‹(Kâˆ’1)2â€‹Ïµâ€‹LfÎ¼}ğ¿ğ¾subscriptğ¿ğ‘”ğ¾12italic-Ïµsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğœ‡L\geq\min\left\{K,\sqrt{\frac{L_{g}(K-1)}{2\epsilon}}\frac{L_{f}}{\mu}\right\}, then the DP-FFL algorithm and the DP-FFL mechanism lead to the following inequality:

RBk,Î´Fâ€‹Fâ€‹Lâ‰¤RBk,Î´L+Ïµ+Dâ€‹Lf2â€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(Kâ€‹n(1))â€‹logâ¡(1/Î²)n(1)2â€‹Î±2subscriptsuperscriptRBğ¹ğ¹ğ¿ğ‘˜ğ›¿subscriptsuperscriptRBğ¿ğ‘˜ğ›¿italic-Ïµğ·superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“2ğ‘‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘›11ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘›12superscriptğ›¼2\displaystyle{\rm RB}^{FFL}_{k,\delta}\leq~{}~{}{\rm RB}^{L}_{k,\delta}+\epsilon+D\frac{L_{f}^{2}d\log(Kn_{(1)})\log(1/\beta)}{n_{(1)}^{2}\alpha^{2}}
+Aâ€‹(1+logâ¡(Bâ€‹logâ¡(Câˆ’1)A)logâ¡(Câˆ’1))ğ´1ğµsuperscriptğ¶1ğ´superscriptğ¶1\displaystyle+A\left(\frac{1+\log(\frac{B\log(C^{-1})}{A})}{\log(C^{-1})}\right) (61)

for all agents kâˆˆğ’¦,ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K}, where RBk,Î´LsubscriptsuperscriptRBğ¿ğ‘˜ğ›¿{\rm RB}^{L}_{k,\delta} and RBk,Î´Fâ€‹Fâ€‹LsubscriptsuperscriptRBğ¹ğ¹ğ¿ğ‘˜ğ›¿{\rm RB}^{FFL}_{k,\delta} are defined in (40) and (41), respectively.

We note that, as implied in Corollary 3, performing local learning does not incur privacy loss for individual agents. Therefore, comparing the results in Corollary 3 and Proposition 7, the DP-FFL algorithm leads to a worse risk bound than the FFL algorithm.

Finally, Proposition 11 also implies that the DP-FFL mechanism achieves budget balance (E4) approximately. We present the detailed analysis in [55].

VII Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate our proposed FFL and DP-FFL mechanisms with K=10ğ¾10K=10 agents. We consider regularized multinomial logistic regression for the MNIST dataset with 60,000 training samples and 10,000 testing samples [54]. We uniformly randomly allocate samples with label yğ‘¦y to all agents whose last digits of their indices are yğ‘¦y. For each sample allocated to agents, with a probability of 1âˆ’Î”1Î”1-\Delta, we reallocate this sample to a random agent with equal probabilities. Therefore, the degree of heterogeneity in this non-i.i.d. data can be characterized by Î”Î”\Delta; a larger Î”Î”\Delta leads to greater data heterogeneity.

For performance comparison, we compare our proposed FFL and DP-FFL schemes against two benchmarks: i) a gradient-based local learning benchmark, in which agents independently solve (11), and ii) a manipulated FedAvg benchmark, in which the server intends to execute FedAvg [3], while one agent manipulates the federated learning algorithm by multiplying its gradient report by an amplifying coefficient Î³ğ›¾\gamma in each iteration. We compare the global loss, Fâ€‹(ğ’˜)ğ¹ğ’˜F(\boldsymbol{w}), and the weighted average test accuracy achieved by different schemes.

Impact of the total number of training samples: We study the impact of the number of total training data samples nğ‘›n in Fig. 4. First, we show that our proposed schemes significantly outperform the manipulated FedAvg, implying that federated learning manipulated even only by one agent can lead to significant performance loss. Therefore, it demonstrates the importance of faithful implementation of federated learning algorithms. Second, both proposed schemes outperform local learning with respect to either global loss and test accuracy. This also indicates that agents are willing to voluntarily participate in federated learning, as both proposed schemes achieve smaller overall losses. We observe that the total number of training data samples nğ‘›n has a greater impact on both local learning and the manipulated FedAvg benchmarks than the proposed (FFL and DP-FFL) mechanisms. This is because the performances both benchmarks are more sensitive to the sizes of local datasets, compared to federated learning.

Impact of non-i.i.d. data: We next study the impact of varying the heterogeneity in the data given by Î”Î”\Delta in Fig. 4. As shown in Fig. 4, Î”Î”\Delta only has an impact on local learning but not on the proposed mechanisms. In Fig. 4(a), we show that, in terms of each individual agentâ€™s objective (overall loss), the DP-FFL and the FFL mechanisms outperform local learning, when Î”â‰¤0.15Î”0.15\Delta\leq 0.15. Local learning is more beneficial, compared to federated learning, when the agents have considerably non-i.i.d. data distributions (i.e., Î”â‰¥0.15Î”0.15\Delta\geq 0.15). In particular, a higher degree of heterogeneous data implies each agent has a higher portion of (both training and test) data samples with labels corresponding to its own index (e.g., agent 333 may have more (both training and test) data samples with label 333 when Î”Î”\Delta increases). This means that individual local datasets are more â€œusefulâ€ when Î”Î”\Delta is large, therefore, incurring a higher test accuracy for local learning. Finally, Fig. 4 (a) and (b) imply whenever local learning is less beneficial than the proposed mechanisms regarding the test accuracy, the FFL and the DP-FFL schemes are more profitable for individual agents, which is consistent with our risk-bound-based voluntary participation results in Proposition 7 and Corollary 3 under Assumption 3.

Impacts of privacy risk Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the number of group Lğ¿L. We study the impacts of the privacy risk Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the number of groups Lğ¿L in Fig. 5. Note that the manipulated FedAvg and the proposed FFL algorithm are not directly comparable here, as they cannot guarantee differential privacy. We set Î”=0.05Î”0.05\Delta=0.05 and K=10ğ¾10K=10. Fig. 5 (a) shows that both the mean and the standard deviation of the payment accuracy loss decrease in Î±ğ›¼\alpha, as a larger privacy risk Î±ğ›¼\alpha leads to less noise in the DP-FFL algorithm. An interesting observation is that, to attain a reasonably small payment accuracy loss, one should choose a small T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} for a small Î±ğ›¼\alpha, which is consistent with Proposition 11. Fig. 5 (b) shows that increasing the number of groups Lğ¿L reduces the payment accuracy loss. In addition, a relatively large enough number of groups (i.e., Lâ‰¥4ğ¿4L\geq 4) is enough to maintain a relative small payment accuracy loss.

VIII Conclusions

We have studied an economic approach to federated learning robust against strategic agentsâ€™ manipulation. We have analyzed how the key feature of federated learning, unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data, affects agentsâ€™ incentive to voluntarily participate and obediently follow federated learning algorithms. We have designed the first faithful mechanism for federated learning, achieving (provably approximately) optimality, faithful implementation, voluntary participation, with the time complexity (in terms of the number of agents Kğ¾K) of ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡K)ğ’ªğ¾\mathcal{O}(\log{K}). We have further presented the differentially private faithful federated learning mechanism, which is the first differentially private faithful mechanism. It provides scalability, maintains the economic properties, and enables one to make three-way performance tradeoffs among privacy, convergence, and payment accuracy loss.

There are a few future directions. First, we assume that the (energy) cost of computation and communication is negligible. It is important to consider and analyze the impacts of such cost, and design economic mechanisms that is not only faithful but also elicits the right amount of efforts. Second, it is also interesting to design faithful algorithms and corresponding economic mechanisms for other more sophisticated federated learning architectures (e.g., multi-task federated learning [13]).
